data.title: Masjid Sultan Muzaffar Shah, Pattani
meta_keywords: มัสยิดกรือเซะ
มัสยิดปิตูกรือบัน
data.meta_description: Masjid Sultan Muzaffar Shah, Pattani, Thailand "Village elders and visitors. The authorities allow daily prayers inside the mosque provided the restored exterior is not tampered with cosmetic outlook to preserve the structure. Apparently, the interior can be furnished and improved to suit its purpose as a prayer hall". Krue Se Mosque (Malay: Masjid Kerisek / Kerisik, Kerisek, Krisek;[a] Keresik, Kresik, Kresek, Krue Se, Gresik; Thai: มัสยิดกรือเซะ, RTGS: Matsayit Kruese) also called Gresik Mosque, Pitu Krue-ban Mosque / Masjid Pintu Gerbang (Thai: มัสยิดปิตูกรือบัน) or Sultan Muzaffar Shah Mosque. Its construction may have begun in the 16th century believed ca. 1524 during the reign of Sultan Muzaffar Shah. The surviving structure features a mixture of Middle Eastern and European architectural styles. Ref.: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krue_Se_Mosque ms.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masjid_Kersik
data.text:
Masjid Sultan Muzaffar Shah, Pattani, Thailand

"Village elders and visitors. The authorities allow daily prayers inside the mosque provided the restored exterior is not tampered with cosmetic outlook to preserve the structure. Apparently, the interior can be furnished and improved to suit its purpose as a prayer hall".

Krue Se Mosque (Malay: Masjid Kerisek / Kerisik, Kerisek, Krisek;[a] Keresik, Kresik, Kresek, Krue Se, Gresik; Thai: มัสยิดกรือเซะ, RTGS: Matsayit Kruese) also called Gresik Mosque, Pitu Krue-ban Mosque / Masjid Pintu Gerbang (Thai: มัสยิดปิตูกรือบัน) or Sultan Muzaffar Shah Mosque.

Its construction may have begun in the 16th century believed ca. 1524 during the reign of Sultan Muzaffar Shah. The surviving structure features a mixture of Middle Eastern and European architectural styles.

Ref.:

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krue_Se_Mosque

ms.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masjid_Kersik
